document.text: Advertisements of a loyal subject to his gracious Sovereign drawn from the observations of the peoples speeches but is a libellous exception against sum proceeding of the stat sinc the Kings CommingIt is said þt your magistie will not continue the protection of the lowe countries, they be the only yokefellowes as it wear of your religion, & although doubtless your magisties high wisdom will hear and see all inconveniences, yet the simple gospellers morn for your resolution, and god grant your magistie repent not there dissentiones or else destructiones, for if the Spannard prevail against those forsaken men, his forces by Sea are more then trebled, peace will enrich him, wealth will add to his pride, his pride will increase, his hatred to your religion & people and the Pope the firebrand of dissension, even then when you are despoiled of your best aid, will discover his wonted malice against us. The prentended title of the infant is not unknown to your Maigistie, yet shall not want the Anti christian furtherance, the Spannard is his dearest child, your kingdom shall by his unholy holiness be given fortiori: Alas they shall have no work at home, it will be but sport for them to war upon you: Principijs obsto sero medicina paratur: It is said þt , if your Magistie discontinewe the leage with the States, the French are ready to entertain the bargain: There is a certain Antipathy between them and vs, and that is hard to judge whether the Spannard or the french will prove worse neighbours unto you, your true Subjects therefore pray you to keep them both at the staffes end, It it said, þt your magistie doth receive an infinite number of petitions & the power foolish people think the king hath leisure to attend every private business, Rid your hands beetymes of such importunities and except your magistie see great cause to the contrary, refer them to the ordinary course of justice ordained for the ending of all differences, But if any complain truly againest the chief officers, of what place & dignity soever they be, hear them your self gracious Sovereign, make but one or two examples of justice, & we shall find a golden change suddenly, but yet the law Talionis must be put in ur and the unjust accuser, must be severally punished It is said your magestie gives much, Liberality in a prince is a necessary virtue, but your confers are said not to be so full, as þt they need emptinge nor your estate in so great security, þt it may endure a lean treasury, after two or three years trial of your neighbours confederates & there affections & the better understanding of your owen fortunes & occasions, your magistie shall better decern out of what plenty, in what manner, & to whom to give your subjects have bine of late years charged with many Subsidies & with out doubt wonder þt your highness doth not remit the remainder of the taxes and Subsides still behind, they say it hath bine the custom of kings at there entrance unto the crown so to do, and there hope in that case is deceived, they pray you not to follow the opinion of king Rohaboams young counsellors not to suffer the long use of taxes and Subsidies to turn unto an habit, for they vow in defence of your majesty the Gospel and the state, they will be prodigal of there lives and living, They say that some be advanced to places of justice altogether unfit for them, in that they are ignorant of our laws and custumes, our advancements to those of the gowen were wont to be as those of the Field, from an old Soldier to a lieutenant, from a lieutenant to a Captain and so orderly every place in the camp, now in deed in the danger this is some difference, for an unskilful general can seldom offend more then once, and his life and all pays for it. But such a Magistrate by a thousand ignorants may peradventure enrich himself, and wrong a number of poor people. It is said that the mastership of the Rolls shall be executed by a deputy the is held for a wise and honourable gentleman but the deputy now spoken of is not of honest fame, and god forbid that so good a king should make so bad a president as to suffer a chief place of justice to be Performed or rather abused by a deputy, or that the should make sale of your majesties fair gift, the place was in a manner executed (before such wear the judges) by deputy, which pro tempore wear commissioners, but the due use of the afternoon which the master of the Rolls did usually spend to hear & to end many causes was a chief want, where of the Client complained, which course it is said the master now being, cannot follow by reason of his more near and necessary employments about your majesty./It is said that the respect at the court of the Scottish by all the attendant officers there is so partial, that the English find them selves much disgraced, the meanest of that country may enter þe presence and were not with one controlled but the English men very unseasonably I wis are kept out, the fault is not said to be your Majesties, but is the foolish gross clauing of some of the English, but your Majesty must provide least such discretion breed an indiscreet æmulacon between vs, who ought as we profess but one god and one king so to have but one heart and your English Subjects ought not to be disgraced, for it must be confessed right noble king that the kingdom and people of England made you great, many offices have bine taken from the English and given to the Scottish, and some that have served the state with good commendation which now you must esteem done to your self remain unthought of and unrewarded./It is said that your Majesty purposes to alter the manner of government and that fault was found with common law and customs of England and especially our trials by oath of xij men which is with out doubt the best & equalised course and in it self lest capable of corruption, every alteration even in a private family, much more in kingdoms breeds hurts doubtless there be abuses even in the courts at Westmaster and chiefly in the Arbitrary Courts, but yet your Majesty hade but once purified a few of the chiefest officers, how suddenly would your Majesty with one experience give the highest allowance to our common laws and statutes which be ever fitted with the occurents and natures of the people of this kingdom.) It is said that your Majesty of an ingenious and royal nature not delighting in our popular salutations, do pass by great tropes of your commons with a kind of kingly negligence nether speaking, nor looking upon them, the poor sort of people are bold with your majesty: they prate of the manner of there late Queen, wh when she was publicly abroad would often stay & speak kindly to the multitude, discovering her royal accepture of there joyful acclamacon and many times also saying that her subjects hungry eyes might have there fill in beholding there Sovereign: your majesty must needs therefore in some sort satisfy there Jealous affections, the poor rascals so far as they dare will be angry with you.) It is said that your majesties followers as well English as Scottish do proclaim open sale of the most noble and ancient order of knighthood, whereby some contrary to your Highness intent of unworthy condition have for bribery bine unworthily made knights, to the dishonour of your royal Majesty and the disgrace of other noble virtuous knights.) The kingdom and people of England made you great, many offices have bine taken from the English and given to the Scottish, and some that have served the state with good commendations which now you must esteem done to your self The Plebes I wot not what they call them, but some there be who most unnaturally & vnreverentlie by most egregious lies, wound the honour of our deceased Sovereign, not only touching her government & good fame but her person with sundry untruths, and the foolish indigesta moles, your commons of London I should say some of them, for doubtless all are not so lewd have put out the name where it was engraven, and painted under the arms of the kingdom And it is said þt they are about to alter certain monuments once dedicated to her as loath belike to be at any new cost with your Majesty Suerlie these slanders be the doings of the Papists aiming thereby at the deformation of the Gospel, we will therefore pray your majesty truly magnanimous to provide for the preservation of famous memory by all good means./ It is said that many ancient and poor officers at Court be displaced & there places given to your country men the Scots in deed to say true, it is meet þt your majesties true servants should be foer your majesties nearest impoloyment, nor is it any dishonour to the English nation þt your good servants be preferred so that your majesty leave not the well deserving disgraced, the people are rightly termed a beast of many heads, so many men so many minds, yet such is the work of god, I hear every man loves and reverences your majesty, let therefore the admirable name of your majesties coming to so opulent a kingdom be ever before your eyes: God is chiefly to be honoured, religion to be more and more advanced, & the common wealth to be cherished, which consists chiefly of home borne men, it wear good we could forget all difference of names and repair the almost decayed name of great Brittane. doubt-lesse unto so wise a prince a word is enough and therefore poor I have always in my private conference maintained your majesties just title so far as I durst, will here end. Blessing my god that I see these happy days, where in the kingdoms so long disjoined be now united in one royal person whose posterity I would so obey god as they shall continue kings of this land, until the dissolution of the universal/ Advertisement of a Loyal subject
